sections.title: Know the Market Before You Close
sections.subtitle: Validate rents, neighborhoods, and red flags so every property matches your strategy

sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: Collecting neighborhood data that predicts rent growth
Evaluating crime, school, and employment trends
Reviewing seller disclosures, inspections, and title work
Creating a due diligence timeline that keeps deals on track

sections.title: Start with Location Intelligence
sections.content: Evaluate job growth, population trends, and infrastructure projects in the submarket. Use census data, municipal plans, and rental comparables to confirm demand. Strong markets show steady absorption, rising wages, and diversified industries.

points.title: Physical
points.description: Schedule inspections, review maintenance logs, and estimate capital expenditures over the next 5-10 years.

points.title: Financial
points.description: Verify rent rolls, trailing 12-month operating statements, and tax histories. Look for expenses the seller omitted.

points.title: Legal
points.description: Order title reports, confirm zoning compliance, and review leases for clauses that survive closing.

sections.title: Vacancy Stress Test
sections.content: Model worst-case scenarios with 10-15% vacancy and higher turnover costs. If the deal still cash flows, you have a resilient property.

sections.title: Work the Timeline
sections.content: Create a closing checklist that allocates inspection periods, financing contingencies, and appraisal deadlines. Communicate with your lender and title company weekly so no document falls through the cracks.

sections.title: Due Diligence Checklist
steps: Map the neighborhood with a drive-by or virtual walk to note amenities, traffic, and nearby developments.
Pull five comparable rentals and sales to validate price-per-door and achievable rents.
Request and review seller docs: rent rolls, leases, expenses, utility bills, insurance claims.
Order a professional inspection and negotiate repair credits based on findings.
Set calendar reminders for contingency deadlines so you can exit if deal-breakers appear.
